mods.abstract: Savoie discusses his grandfather's influence on his early years. He explains the importance of the Catholic Church in his daily life, growing up, and for his children and their families. He talks about the role of music and dance halls in his youth, and how he helped to bring musicians to the bayou. Savoie discusses the importance of volunteering in the community, including his own role in the development of the Oyster Festival. Savoie discusses the various homes he has lived in, and the changing demographics of Bayou Lafourche, in terms of religion and race.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.2089. A digital version of the index (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Chaffie Jenkins and Amber Breaux.

Ted Savoie was born in 1943 in Galliano, Louisiana, to a family with Acadian heritage (descendants of François Savoie). He spent his childhood living with his immediate family and maternal grandfather, who was in the oyster business and a community leader. Savoie's father was originally a farmer from Larose, but entered the oyster business and then the tugboat business, which Savoie eventually took over. Savoie is active in church and civic activities, and the father of four children and many grandchildren.
